SIAMCAT
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • SIAMCAT: Statistical Inference of Associations between Microbial Communities And host phenoTypes

    SIAMCAT: Statistical Inference of Associations between Microbial Communities And host phenoTypes

    Konrad Zych, Jakob Wirbel, Nicolai Karcher, and Georg Zeller

    2018-01-02

    Introduction

    SIAMCAT Workflow

    library(SIAMCAT)
fn.in.feat <- system.file("extdata", "feat_crc_study-pop-I_N141_tax_profile_mocat_bn_specI_clusters.tsv", package = "SIAMCAT")
fn.in.label <- system.file("extdata", "label_crc_study-pop-I_N141_tax_profile_mocat_bn_specI_clusters.tsv", package = "SIAMCAT")
fn.in.meta <- system.file("extdata", "num_metadata_crc_study-pop-I_N141_tax_profile_mocat_bn_specI_clusters.tsv", package = "SIAMCAT")

    Read/Validate/Filter Data

    feat  <- read.features(fn.in.feat)
    ## The provided feature names were not semantically correct for use in R, they were updated.
    label <- read.labels(fn.in.label)
meta  <- read.meta(fn.in.meta)
siamcat <- siamcat(feat, label, meta)

    add workflow from a disk

    keep in mind holdout prediction

    check dtaa consistency function

    CI low abudandt accuracy

    siamcat <- validate.data(siamcat)
    siamcat <- select.samples(siamcat, 
                          filter='age', 
                          allowed.set=NULL, 
                          allowed.range=c(0,120))
    ## allowed.range  = [0,120]
## Removed 0 samples with age not in [0, 120] (retaining 141)
## Keeping labels of 141 sample(s).
    siamcat <- filter.feat(siamcat,  
                       filter.method = 'abundance', 
                       cutoff =0.001, 
                       recomp.prop = FALSE, 
                       rm.unmapped = TRUE)
    ## [1] 1754
## Removed 1 features corresponding to UNMAPPED reads
## Removed 1546 features whose values did not exceed 0.001 in any sample (retaining 207)
## phyloseq-class experiment-level object
## otu_table()   OTU Table:         [ 207 taxa and 141 samples ]
## sample_data() Sample Data:       [ 141 samples by 8 sample variables ]

    Association/Confounder Testing

    confounder.check(siamcat, fn.plot='conf_check.pdf')
    ## checking Age as a potential confounder...
    ## checking Gender as a potential confounder...
    ## checking Bmi as a potential confounder...
    ## checking Diagnosis as a potential confounder...
    ## checking Localization as a potential confounder...
    ## checking Crc stage as a potential confounder...
    ## checking Fobt as a potential confounder...
    ## checking Wif test as a potential confounder...
    check.associations(siamcat,
                   sort.by='fc',
                   fn.plot = 'assoc.pdf',
                   alpha = 0.05, mult.corr = "fdr",
                   detect.lim = 10^-6, max.show = 50, plot.type = "quantile.box",
                   panels=c("fc", "prevalence", "auroc"))
    ## Found 23 significant associations at a significance level < 0.05
    ## Successfully created association plot...

    Data Normalization

    siamcat <- normalize.feat(siamcat, 
                          norm.method = "log.unit", 
                          norm.param=list(log.n0 = 1e-06, n.p=2, norm.margin=1))
    ## Performing de novo normalization using the  log.unit  method
## Feature sparsity before normalization: 45.11598%
## Feature sparsity after normalization: 0%

    Model building and Prediction

    pred.names = strsplit(c('fobt'), ',', fixed=TRUE)[[1]]
siamcat <- add.meta.pred(siamcat, 
                          pred.names = pred.names, 
                          std.meta = TRUE)
    ## adding fobt
## filling in 1 missing values by mean imputation
## standardize metadata feature fobt 
## added 1 meta-variables as predictors to the feature matrix

    vignette for cv/holdout

    int verbose for each function (0,5) with def=1

    siamcat <- data.splitter(siamcat, 
                            num.folds = 5, ### holdout -> all train/ all test etc, cross-validation/holdout -> make rest defaults
                            num.resample = 2, 
                            stratify = TRUE, 
                            inseparable = NULL)
    ## [1] 5
## 
## +++ Splitting the dataset:
##    + Fold 1 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 2 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 3 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 4 contains 27 examples
##    + Fold 5 contains 27 examples
## [1] 5
## 
## +++ Splitting the dataset:
##    + Fold 1 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 2 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 3 contains 29 examples
##    + Fold 4 contains 27 examples
##    + Fold 5 contains 27 examples
    siamcat <- train.model(siamcat, 
                       method = "lasso",
                       data.split=data.split, #??
                       stratify = TRUE,
                       modsel.crit=list("pr"),  
                       min.nonzero.coeff = 5,
                       param.set=NULL)
    ## cv_fold1_rep1 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold1_rep2 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold2_rep1 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold2_rep2 contains 112 training examples
## cv_fold3_rep1 contains 112 training examples

    siamcat <- make.predictions(siamcat)
    ## cv_fold1_rep1 contains 29 training examples

    Model Evaluation and Interpretation

    siamcat <-  eval.predictions(siamcat)

evaluation.model.plot(siamcat,'eval_plot.pdf')
    ## AU-ROC (resampled run 1): 0.76
## AU-ROC (resampled run 2): 0.779
## Mean-pred. AU-ROC: 0.786 
## Averaged AU-ROC: 0.769 (sd=0.01357)
    ## AU-PRC (resampled run 1): 0.658
## AU-PRC (resampled run 2): 0.659
## Mean-pred. AU-PRC: 0.679 
## Averaged AU-PRC: 0.769 (sd=0.01357)
    interpretor.model.plot(siamcat,
                        fn.plot='interpretation.pdf',
                        consens.thres = 0.5,
                        norm.models = TRUE,
                        limits=c(-5,5),
                        heatmap.type = 'fc')
    ## + interpretor.model.plot
